page.title: 01Buckden and Grafham
page.content: There are two settlements within the survey block, Buckden and Grafham. The undulating land between them is devoted to arable farming. The fields are hedged although some have been joined. Primroses and cowslips grow along the disused railwayline between the two villages. Grafham, which gives its name to the nearby resevoir is a small village with only one shop and a public house. To the north of the village is Brampton Wood, an MOD firing range. Between the two villages are two or three farms situated on the sides of a shallow valley. The western edge of Buckden is dominated by the noise and litter of the A1 trunk road. We discovered numerous tin cans as we walked along it. The Ouse Valley to the east of the village is quarried for gravel.
